issues.description: The template repository's StockIngredient class exposes the quantity via a method named retrieveQuantity(), while other template files (Stock.add/take and Main) and the solution use getQuantity(). This name mismatch is an unintentional structural inconsistency: code in the template expects getQuantity() to exist and will not compile against the provided StockIngredient. Also, the problem statement asks students to "add getters for all the private fields" which implies the conventional getX naming; the template's retrieveQuantity() deviates from that convention and from the solution, which may confuse students and block compilation.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the quantity getter in the template StockIngredient class from retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity(), or add a public getQuantity() method that delegates to retrieveQuantity(). Ensure getter naming is consistent across files (Stock, Main, tests) and follows the conventional getX pattern requested in the problem statement.

issues.description: The template repository defines StockIngredient.retrieveQuantity() while the rest of the code (template Stock.java and the solution) expects / implements getQuantity(). The problem statement asks students to “add getters for all the private fields” but does not name the getter; the common Java convention and the solution use getQuantity(). Having retrieveQuantity() in the template breaks the expected mapping and will cause compilation errors / extra confusion for students trying to match the problem text to the provided code and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template method StockIngredient.retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() (and keep the existing setQuantity). This matches Java getter conventions, aligns the template with the Stock class usage and the solution, and removes an unintended compile-time / mapping burden for students.
